articles.headline: Stock Markets Are Wild, but Bond Markets Can Be Dangerous
articles.snippet: The sell-off in stocks isn’t the only ominous economic sign emanating from financial markets. The bond markets, much more closely linked to the actual economy, are also flashing a warning.
articles.abstract: The sell-off in stocks isn’t the only ominous economic sign emanating from financial markets. The bond markets, much more closely linked to the actual economy, are also flashing a warning.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ask someone how “the Dow” is doing and, even if they don’t know the answer, they’ll know what you’re talking about. Ask them about the bond market and you’ll most likely get a blank stare.
articles.byline: By Matt Phillips and Peter Eavis

articles.headline: CBS Is Footing Moonves’s Legal Bills, Giving Him an Incentive to Fight
articles.snippet: When CBS ousted its former chief executive, it agreed to pay his legal bills into the future — an arrangement likely to cost CBS tens of millions.
articles.abstract: When CBS ousted its former chief executive, it agreed to pay his legal bills into the future — an arrangement likely to cost CBS tens of millions.

articles.headline: The Market Is Worried. The Economy Is Strong. How Will the Fed React?
articles.snippet: The Fed had an easy 2018, raising rates amid strong growth, and it’s expected to cap the year with one more increase on Wednesday. But 2019 is likely to pose greater challenges.
articles.abstract: The Fed had an easy 2018, raising rates amid strong growth, and it’s expected to cap the year with one more increase on Wednesday. But 2019 is likely to pose greater challenges.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The challenge confronting the Federal Reserve as it meets this week is a tale of two economies. Wall Street investors are behaving as if the economic expansion is in grave danger, while the best available data show that the American economy has continued to grow at a healthy pace.

articles.headline: Senate Passes Bipartisan Criminal Justice Bill
articles.snippet: The Senate passed the most substantial changes in a generation to federal prison and sentencing laws. The House will follow, and President Trump is expected to sign it.
articles.abstract: The Senate passed the most substantial changes in a generation to federal prison and sentencing laws. The House will follow, and President Trump is expected to sign it.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate overwhelmingly approved on Tuesday the most substantial changes in a generation to the tough-on-crime prison and sentencing laws that ballooned the federal prison population and created a criminal justice system that many conservatives and liberals view as costly and unfair.

articles.headline: As Facebook Raised a Privacy Wall, It Carved an Opening for Tech Giants
articles.snippet: Internal documents show that the social network gave Microsoft, Amazon, Spotify and others far greater access to people’s data than it has disclosed.
articles.abstract: Internal documents show that the social network gave Microsoft, Amazon, Spotify and others far greater access to people’s data than it has disclosed.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, Facebook gave some of the world’s largest technology companies more intrusive access to users’ personal data than it has disclosed, effectively exempting those business partners from its usual privacy rules, according to internal records and interviews.
articles.byline: By Gabriel J.X. Dance, Michael LaForgia and Nicholas Confessore

articles.headline: Hacked European Cables Reveal a World of Anxiety About Trump, Russia and Iran
articles.snippet: The cables quote China’s president calling America a bully, show concerns about Russian nuclear weapons in Crimea and detail the White House walking back President Trump’s words.
articles.abstract: The cables quote China’s president calling America a bully, show concerns about Russian nuclear weapons in Crimea and detail the White House walking back President Trump’s words.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Updated Wednesday, Dec. 19: The United Nations spokesman has issued a comment about the breach and the National Security Agency said it would decline to comment. Both are included in the story below.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Steven Erlanger

articles.headline: Japanese Justice Faces Scrutiny in Case of Nissan Chief and U.S. Board Member
articles.snippet: The jailing of Carlos Ghosn and Greg Kelly exposed stark differences in how crimes are pursued and suspects are handled in Japan and in Western democracies.
articles.abstract: The jailing of Carlos Ghosn and Greg Kelly exposed stark differences in how crimes are pursued and suspects are handled in Japan and in Western democracies.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Five months ago, Carlos Ghosn, a multimillionaire executive credited with reviving Nissan Motors, hosted the wedding of his daughter Caroline on Naoshima, a rarefied island enclave of art and sculpture. The celebration began with the cracking open of a barrel of sake, an elegant and traditional way in Japan to toast good fortune.
articles.byline: By Motoko Rich and Jack Ewing

articles.headline: Trump to Withdraw U.S. Forces From Syria, Declaring ‘We Have Won Against ISIS’
articles.snippet: The president overruled his military and diplomatic advisers, who warned against abandoning Kurdish allies and ceding influence in Syria to Russia and Iran.
articles.abstract: The president overruled his military and diplomatic advisers, who warned against abandoning Kurdish allies and ceding influence in Syria to Russia and Iran.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump has ordered the withdrawal of 2,000 American troops from Syria, bringing a sudden end to a military campaign that largely vanquished the Islamic State but ceding a strategically vital country to Russia and Iran.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler, Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt
